items.content_html:
Software üì¶

CRAN: GitHub:

New Packages

  • The first version (v0.1.0) of dittodb is on CRAN - a test environment for database requests. It went through rOpenSci software review recently - check out the reviews. Checkout the docs to get started.

New Versions

  • rdpla is now archived on cran. You can still install it from GitHub but it is no longer maintained.
  • A new version (v1.1-3) of suppdata is on CRAN - downloading supplementary data from published manuscripts. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignette to get started.
  • A new version (v1.1.0) of spocc is on CRAN - an interface to many species occurrence data sources. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.5.0) of ckanr is on CRAN - client for the CKAN API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.0.0) of crul is on CRAN - an R6 based HTTP client for R made for developers. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.5.0) of mapr is on CRAN - visualize species occurrence data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignette to get started.
  • A new version (v0.9.0) of gistr is on CRAN - work with GitHub Gists. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.2.10) of ropenaq is on CRAN - air quality data from the open data platform OpenAQ. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.7.0) of paleobioDB is on CRAN - download and process data from the Paleobiology database. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.7.8) of robotstxt is on CRAN - robots.txt parser and Webbot/Spider/Crawler permissions checker. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.1.2) of ijtiff is on CRAN - comprehensive TIFF I/O with full support for ImageJ TIFF files. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • Two new versions (v2.0.2/v2.0.3) of EML are on CRAN - read and write ecological metadata language files. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v3.2.0) of rgbif is on CRAN - interface to the Global Biodiversity Information Facility API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the occurrence manual to get started.
  • A new version (v1.3.0) of credentials is on CRAN - tools for managing ssh and git credentials. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.7.0) of ssh is on CRAN - secure shell (SSH) client for R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignette to get started.



Software Review ‚úî


Software review is now accepting submissions again.

We accept community contributed packages via our software review system - an open software review system, sorta like scholarly paper review, but way better. We‚Äôll highlight newly onboarded packages here. A huge thanks to our reviewers, who do a lot of work reviewing (see the blog post on our review system),and the authors of the packages!

If you want to be a reviewer fill out this short form, and we‚Äôll ping you when there‚Äôs a submission that fits in your area of expertise.


No new submissions or approved submissions.



Citations

The following 20 works use/cite rOpenSci software:

  • Scharm√ºller et al. used bib2df, plotly, rgbif, taxize and webchem in their paper Standartox: Standardizing Toxicity Data 1
  • Nguyen et al. used MODIStsp in their paper Factors affecting urban electricity consumption: a case study in the Bangkok Metropolitan Area using an integrated approach of earth observation data and data analysis 2
  • Upadhya et al. used rtimicropem in their paper mmaqshiny v1.0: R-Shiny package to explore Air-Quality Mobile-Monitoring data 3
  • Rahman et al. used rtweet in their paper Twitter and Census Data Analytics to Explore Socioeconomic Factors for Post-COVID-19 Reopening Sentiment 4
  • Colling et al. used magick in their paper A multilab registered replication of the attentional SNARC effect 5
  • Lam et al. used skimr in their paper Use of random forest analysis to quantify the importance of the structural characteristics of beta-glucans for prebiotic development 6
  • Deconinck et al. used rnaturalearth in their paper A high-quality genetic reference database for European commercial fishes reveals substitution fraud of processed Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua) and common sole (Solea solea) at different steps in the Belgian supply chain 7
  • Bohora Schlickmann et al. used rgbif in their paper Specific leaf area is a potential indicator of tree species sensitive to future climate change in the mixed Subtropical Forests of southern Brazil 8
  • Shrestha & Shrestha used geojsonio in their paper Group segmentation and heterogeneity in the choice of cooking fuels in post-earthquake Nepal 9
  • Crowley et al. used rotl and taxize in their paper Identifying Suspect Bat Reservoirs of Emerging Infections 10
  • Joyce et al. used rgbif in their paper Checklist of the vascular flora of the Sunda-Sahul Convergence Zone 11
  • Camacho used rtweet in their paper Sentiment mapping: Point pattern analysis of sentiment classified twitter data 12
  • Hau√üner & Klika used rtweet in their paper Who Is Connected to Whom? A Twitter-Based Network Analysis of Members of the European Parliament Elected in 2019 13
  • Petersen et al. used rgbif in their paper Urban aliens and threatened near-naturals: Land-cover affects the species richness of alien- and threatened species in an urban-rural setting 14
  • Lindberg et al. used rgbif in their paper Increased above‚Äêground resource allocation is a likely precursor for independent evolutionary origins of annuality in the Pooideae grass subfamily 15
  • Donnellan et al. used hunspell in their paper How are Curiosity and Interest Different? 16
  • Gold used taxize in their paper Design and Implementation of Environmental DNA Metabarcoding Methods for Monitoring the Southern California Marine Protected Area Network 17
  • Lenoir et al. used taxize and rgbif in their paper Species better track climate warming in the oceans than on land 18
  • De Almeida Monteiro Melo Ferraz et al. used rentrez in their paper Follicular extracellular vesicles enhance meiotic resumption of domestic cat vitrified oocytes 19
  • Joo et al. used fulltext in their paper A decade of movement ecology 20



From the Forum

We have a discussion forum (using Discourse) for the rOpenSci community. It‚Äôs a really nice way to have conversations on the internet. From time to time we‚Äôll highlight recent discussions of interest.


A few new use cases were shared in the forum over the past two weeks since our last newsletter:

  • Pedro Rocha contributed our first use case in Portuguese! Extraindo tabelas de documentos pdf em R com Tabulizer; it leveraged the tabulizer package, an rOpenSci package maintained by Tom Paskhalis
  • Zhi Yang shared: Creating a self-updating GitHub README using rtweet and GitHub Actions; the use case employed the rtweet package, an rOpenSci package maintained by Michael Kearney
  • Rayna Harris shared: Spanish and English blogs on how to use rtweet and magick; it used the rtweet and magick packages, rOpenSci packages maintained by Michael Kearney and Jeroen Ooms, respectively



Call For Maintainers

Part of the mission of rOpenSci is making sustainable software that users can rely on. Some software maintainers need to give up maintenance due to a variety of circumstances. When that happens we try to find new maintainers. Check out our guidance for taking over maintenance of a package.

We‚Äôve had nine recent examples of maintainer transitions within rOpenSci:

  • RSelenium: now maintained by Ju Kim
  • chromer: now maintained by Paula Andrea
  • qualtRics: now maintained by Julia Silge
  • rsnps: now maintained by Julia Gustavsen and Sina R√ºeger
  • webchem: now maintained by Erik Sapper
  • mregions: in process of moving to maintenance by VLIZ
  • rWBclimate: now maintained by Sergio Ibarra-Espinosa and Amanda Rehbein
  • rinat: now maintained by St√©phane Guillou



Get involved with rOpenSci

We maintain a Contributing Guide that can help direct you to the right place, whether you want to make code contributions, non-code contributions, or other things like sharing use cases.





Keep up with rOpenSci

  • Mailing list: Sign up with an email address to get this newsletter sent to your inbox -> ropensci.org/#subscribe
  • Alternatively, you can subscribe to this newsletter via our XML feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.xml or our JSON feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.json
  • rOpenSci on Twitter: @ropensci
  • The rOpenSci blog at ropensci.org/blog - you can subscribe in any RSS aggregator, or manually via https://ropensci.org/feed.xml. We also announce new blog posts on our Twitter account.

Software üì¶

CRAN: GitHub:

New Versions

  • A new version (v0.1.9) of codemetar is on CRAN - Generate codemeta metadata for R packages. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.3.2) of UCSCXenaTools is on CRAN - download and explore datasets from UCSC Xena data hubs. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.1.2) of chirps is on CRAN - client for the Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station Data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.5.0) of emld is on CRAN - ecological metadata as linked data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.1.0) of rnoaa is on CRAN - NOAA Weather Data from R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.6.2) of stplanr is on CRAN - sustainable transport planning. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.4.2) of worrms is on CRAN - client for World Register of Marine Species. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.5.0) of iheatmapr is on CRAN - Interactive and complex heatmaps. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.4.0) of rcoreoa is on CRAN - client for CORE https://core.ac.uk/. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.



Software Review ‚úî


Software review is now accepting submissions again.

We accept community contributed packages via our software review system - an open software review system, sorta like scholarly paper review, but way better. We‚Äôll highlight newly onboarded packages here. A huge thanks to our reviewers, who do a lot of work reviewing (see the blog post on our review system),and the authors of the packages!

If you want to be a reviewer fill out this short form, and we‚Äôll ping you when there‚Äôs a submission that fits in your area of expertise.


The following two packages were recently submitted:

  • readODS > Read and Write ODS Files
    • Author: Chung-hong Chan
    • Issue: ropensci/software-review#386
    • Reviewers: not yet assigned
  • phonfieldwork > Linguistic Phonetic Fieldwork Tools
    • Author: George Moroz
    • Issue: ropensci/software-review#385
    • Reviewers:
      • Jonathan Keane
      • 2nd reviewer not assigned yet



Use Cases

The following 30 works use/cite rOpenSci software:

  • Adams et al. used nlrx in their paper Ten questions concerning the microbiomes of buildings 1
  • Dunnett et al. used osmdata in their paper Harmonised global datasets of wind and solar farm locations and power 2
  • Morand et al. used rotl in their paper Disease Ecology of Rickettsial Species: A Data Science Approach 3
  • D. & L used camsRad in their paper Solar Project Financing, Bankability, and Resource Assessment 4
  • Hannon et al. used RSelenium in their paper Use and abuse of dietary supplements in persons with diabetes 5
  • Neuts et al. used RSelenium in their paper Topics and Sentiments in Online Place Reviews, an Innovative Way of Understanding the Perception of a City without Asking 6
  • Chandler et al. used taxize in their paper Rocket Science: The Effect of Spaceflight on Germination Physiology, Ageing, and Transcriptome of Eruca sativa Seeds 7
  • Greenhalgh et al. used rtweet in their paper Identifying multiple learning spaces within a single teacher-focused Twitter hashtag 8
  • F√§rber et al. used rfishbase in their paper Population variability under stressors is dependent on body mass growth and asymptotic body size 9
  • Pyle et al. used MODISTools in their paper Yearling proportion correlates with habitat structure in a boreal forest landbird community 10
  • Verhoeven et al. used taxize in their paper Niche Models Differentiate Potential Impacts of Two Aquatic Invasive Plant Species on Native Macrophytes 11
  • Eastman et al. used rnaturalearth in their paper Remdesivir: A Review of Its Discovery and Development Leading to Emergency Use Authorization for Treatment of COVID-19 12
  • Ozturk & Altinok used rnaturalearth in their paper Interaction of Plastics with Marine Species 13
  • DellaPosta & Nee used hunspell in their paper Emergence of diverse and specialized knowledge in a metropolitan tech cluster 14
  • Ladwig et al. used taxize in their paper A taxonomic, phylogenetic, and functional comparison of restoration seed mixes and historical plant communities in Midwestern oak savannas 15
  • Deza-Araujo et al. used neotoma in their paper A critical assessment of human-impact indices based on anthropogenic pollen indicators 16
  • Yang & Bright used camsRad in their paper Worldwide validation of 8 satellite-derived and reanalysis solar radiation products: A preliminary evaluation and overall metrics for hourly data over 27 years. Solar Energy 17
  • Enkhbayar et al. used rplos in their paper How much research shared on Facebook happens outside of public pages and groups? A comparison of public and private online activity around PLOS ONE papers 18
  • Berg et al. used taxize in their paper Potential impact of chemical stress on freshwater invertebrates: A sensitivity assessment on continental and national scale based on distribution patterns, biological traits, and relatedness 19
  • Carroll et al. used neotoma in their paper Ragweed and sagebrush pollen can distinguish between vegetation types at broad spatial scales 20
  • Kang et al. used UCSCXenaTools in their paper The SLC Family Are Candidate Diagnostic and Prognostic Biomarkers in Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma 21
  • Feldmann et al. used magick in their paper Multi-dimensional machine learning approaches for fruit shape phenotyping in strawberry 22
  • Marple used textreuse in their paper The social management of complex uncertainty: Central Bank similarity and crisis liquidity swaps at the Federal Reserve 23
  • Bubac et al. used rotl in their paper The genetic basis of animal behavioural diversity in natural populations 24
  • Liu et al. used UCSCXenaTools in their paper Omics-wide quantitative B-cell infiltration analyses identify GPR18 for human cancer prognosis with superiority over CD20 25
  • Callaghan et al. used textreuse in their paper Model State Legislation and Intergovernmental Tensions over the Affordable Care Act, Common Core, and the Second Amendment 26
  • Rogers et al. used taxize in their paper Critical Habitats and Biodiversity: Inventory, Thresholds and Governance 27
  • Holzmeyer et al. used geonames in their paper Evaluation of plant sources for antiinfective lead compound discovery by correlating phylogenetic, spatial, and bioactivity data 28
  • Bramlett & Burge used rtweet in their paper God Talk in a Digital Age: How Members of Congress Use Religious Language on Twitter 29
  • Vogler et al. used textreuse in their paper Measuring Media Content Concentration at a Large Scale Using Automated Text Comparisons 30



Call For Maintainers

Part of the mission of rOpenSci is making sustainable software that users can rely on. Some software maintainers need to give up maintenance due to a variety of circumstances. When that happens we try to find new maintainers. Check out our guidance for taking over maintenance of a package.

We‚Äôve had nine recent examples of maintainer transitions within rOpenSci:

  • RSelenium: now maintained by Ju Kim
  • chromer: now maintained by Paula Andrea
  • qualtRics: now maintained by Julia Silge
  • rsnps: now maintained by Julia Gustavsen and Sina R√ºeger
  • rdpla: now maintained by Alyssa Columbus
  • webchem: now maintained by Erik Sapper
  • mregions: in process of moving to maintenance by VLIZ
  • rWBclimate: now maintained by Sergio Ibarra-Espinosa and Amanda Rehbein
  • rinat: now maintained by St√©phane Guillou



Get involved with rOpenSci

We maintain a Contributing Guide that can help direct you to the right place, whether you want to make code contributions, non-code contributions, or other things like sharing use cases.





Keep up with rOpenSci

  • Mailing list: Sign up with an email address to get this newsletter sent to your inbox -> ropensci.org/#subscribe
  • Alternatively, you can subscribe to this newsletter via our XML feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.xml or our JSON feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.json
  • rOpenSci on Twitter: @ropensci
  • The rOpenSci blog at ropensci.org/blog - you can subscribe in any RSS aggregator, or manually via https://ropensci.org/feed.xml. We also announce new blog posts on our Twitter account.

items.content_html:
Software üì¶

CRAN: GitHub:

New packages

  • The first version (v0.1.0) of chirps is on CRAN - client for the Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station Data. Checkout the docs to get started. chirps went through rOpenSci software review.

New Versions

  • A new version (v2.1.2) of skimr is on CRAN - compact and flexible summaries of data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignettes to get started.
  • Two new versions (v2.1.0/v2.1.1) of ijtiff are on CRAN - Comprehensive TIFF I/O with full support for ImageJ TIFF files. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.1.14) of spatsoc is on CRAN - detecting spatial and temporal groups in GPS relocations. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.5.0) of fulltext is on CRAN - full text of scholarly articles across many data sources. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the fulltext book to get started.
  • A new version (v1.1.0) of rcites is on CRAN - access the CITES Speciesplus database. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • Two new versions (v1.2/v1.3) of lightr are on CRAN - read spectrometric data and metadata. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v7.12.4) of drake is on CRAN - a pipeline toolkit for reproducible computation at scale. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.4.0) of wikitaxa is on CRAN - taxonomic information from Wikipedia. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.2.2) of pubchunks is on CRAN - Fetch Sections of XML Scholarly Articles. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the README to get started.
  • A new version (v0.4.0) of crminer is on CRAN - Fetch scholarly full text from Crossref. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the README to get started.
  • A new version (v0.7.7) of robotstxt is on CRAN - robots.txt parser and Webbot/Spider/Crawler permissions checker. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.4.0) of sofa is on CRAN - Connector to CouchDB. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignettes to get started.
  • Two new versions (v1.2.0/v1.2.1) of credentials are on CRAN - tools for managing ssh and git credentials. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.0.0) of rdryad is on CRAN - R client for Dryad. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the README to get started.
  • A new version (v0.3.4) of geojson is on CRAN - Classes for GeoJSON. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignettes to get started.
  • A new version (v2.4.0) of magick is on CRAN - Advanced graphics and Image-Processing in R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignette to get started.
  • Two new versions (v3.0.0/v3.1.0) of rgbif are on CRAN - interface to the Global Biodiversity Information Facility API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the occurrence manual to get started.
  • A new version (v0.6.1) of stplanr is on CRAN - sustainable transport planning. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.



Software Review ‚úî


Software review is now accepting submissions again.

We accept community contributed packages via our software review system - an open software review system, sorta like scholarly paper review, but way better. We‚Äôll highlight newly onboarded packages here. A huge thanks to our reviewers, who do a lot of work reviewing (see the blog post on our review system),and the authors of the packages!

If you want to be a reviewer fill out this short form, and we‚Äôll ping you when there‚Äôs a submission that fits in your area of expertise.


No new submissions or approved submissions.



Use Cases

The following 25 works use/cite rOpenSci software:

  • Rossi used tesseract in their paper Monitoring the vegetation dynamics and stress of mountainous grasslands using a multisensor approach 1
  • Jost & Jansen used magick in their paper A novel approach to analyzing all trials in chronometric mental rotation and description of a flexible extended library of stimuli 2
  • Michaels et al. used magick in their paper Visualizing 50 Years of Cancer Mortality Rates Across the US at Multiple Geographic Levels Using a Synchronized Map and Graph Animation 3
  • Brick et al. used assertr in their paper Risk communication in tables versus text: a registered report randomized trial on ‚Äúfact boxes 4
  • Yang used camsRad in their paper Choice of clear-sky model in solar forecasting 5
  • Stropp et al. used rgbif in their paper The ghosts of forests past and future: deforestation and botanical sampling in the Brazilian Amazon 6
  • Claes & M√§ntyl√§ used tokenizers in their paper 20-MAD‚Äì20 Years of Issues and Commits of Mozilla and Apache Development 7
  • Trugman et al. used brranching in their paper Trait velocities reveal that mortality has driven widespread coordinated shifts in forest hydraulic trait composition 8
  • Zushi et al. used webchem in their paper Mixture Touch: A Web Platform for the Evaluation of Complex Chemical Mixtures 9
  • Martins & Boeckx used taxize in their paper Vocal learning: Beyond the continuum 10
  • Hantgan-Sonko used lingtypology in their paper Synchronic and diachronic strategies of mora preservation in G√∫jjolaay Eegimaa 11
  • Fraser et al. used RSelenium and rcrossref in their paper The relationship between bioRxiv preprints, citations and altmetrics 12
  • Staude et al. used scrubr in their paper Replacements of small- by large-ranged species scale up to diversity loss in Europe‚Äôs temperate forest biome 13
  • Hern√°ndez‚ÄêRojas et al. used rgbif in their paper Latitudinal patterns of species richness and range size of ferns along elevational gradients at the transition from tropics to subtropics 14
  • Cui et al. used rotl in their paper Shoot flammability of vascular plants is phylogenetically conserved and related to habitat fire-proneness and growth form 15
  • Timpano et al. used taxize in their paper Optimization of the second internal transcribed spacer (ITS2) for characterizing land plants from soil 16
  • B√§renstrauch et al. used rentrez in their paper Molecular crosstalk between the endophyte Paraconiothyrium variabile and the phytopathogen Fusarium oxysporum ‚Äì Modulation of lipoxygenase activity and beauvericin production during the interaction 17
  • Zhao & Cao used stplanr in their paper Commuting inequity and its determinants in Shanghai: New findings from big-data analytics 18
  • Mishler et al. used taxize in their paper Spatial phylogenetics of the North American flora 19
  • Sinval & Mar√¥co used skimr in their paper Short Index of Job Satisfaction: Validity evidence from Portugal and Brazil 20
  • Barela et al. used MODIStsp in their paper Relationships between survival and habitat suitability of semi‚Äêaquatic mammals 21
  • Menounos et al. used tidyhydat in their paper Glaciers in the Canadian Columbia Basin 22
  • Bernardi et al. used CoordinateCleaner in their paper Phylogeography and species distribution modeling reveal a historic disjunction for the conifer Podocarpus lambertii 23
  • Mart√≠nez et al. used rentrez in their paper Human access impacts biodiversity of microscopic animals in sandy beaches 24
  • Hagan et al. used pdftools in their paper Suggestions for Improving Invited Speaker Diversity To Reflect Trainee Diversity 25



From the Forum

We have a discussion forum (using Discourse) for the rOpenSci community. It‚Äôs a really nice way to have conversations on the internet. From time to time we‚Äôll highlight recent discussions of interest.


A few new use cases were shared in the forum over the past two weeks since our last newsletter:

  • Wei Yang Tham shared: Using qualtRics to study the effect of COVID-19 on scientists; it leveraged the qualtRics package, an rOpenSci package maintained by Julia Silge
  • Steffi LaZerte shared: Using DataPackageR to create data package Pandemic Papers with Chris Knox; it leveraged the DataPackageR package, an rOpenSci package maintained by Greg Finak
  • Augustus Pendleton shared: Filtering pdfs using RegEx in their body; it leveraged the pdftools package, an rOpenSci package maintained by Jeroen Ooms



Call For Maintainers

Part of the mission of rOpenSci is making sustainable software that users can rely on. Some software maintainers need to give up maintenance due to a variety of circumstances. When that happens we try to find new maintainers. Check out our guidance for taking over maintenance of a package.

We‚Äôve had nine recent examples of maintainer transitions within rOpenSci:

  • RSelenium: now maintained by Ju Kim
  • chromer: now maintained by Paula Andrea
  • qualtRics: now maintained by Julia Silge
  • rsnps: now maintained by Julia Gustavsen and Sina R√ºeger
  • rdpla: now maintained by Alyssa Columbus
  • webchem: now maintained by Erik Sapper
  • mregions: in process of moving to maintenance by VLIZ
  • rWBclimate: now maintained by Sergio Ibarra-Espinosa and Amanda Rehbein
  • rinat: now maintained by St√©phane Guillou

We‚Äôve got one package in need of a new maintainer:

  • rflybase: The current maintainer is looking for a new maintainer. Email Scott if you‚Äôre interested.



Get involved with rOpenSci

We maintain a Contributing Guide that can help direct you to the right place, whether you want to make code contributions, non-code contributions, or other things like sharing use cases.





Keep up with rOpenSci

  • Mailing list: Sign up with an email address to get this newsletter sent to your inbox -> ropensci.org/#subscribe
  • Alternatively, you can subscribe to this newsletter via our XML feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.xml or our JSON feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.json
  • rOpenSci on Twitter: @ropensci
  • The rOpenSci blog at ropensci.org/blog - you can subscribe in any RSS aggregator, or manually via https://ropensci.org/feed.xml. We also announce new blog posts on our Twitter account.

items.content_text: Software üì¶CRAN: GitHub: New Versions  A new version (v2.4.5) of RNeXML is on CRAN - Semantically Rich I/O for the NeXML Format. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.    A new version (v1.1.0) of bold is on CRAN - interface to Bold Systems (http://www.boldsystems.org/) API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.    A new version (v0.1.3) of outsider.base is on CRAN - base package for outsider. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.    A new version (v2.1.1) of GSODR is on CRAN - Global Surface Summary of the Day (GSOD) Weather Data from R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.    A new version (v1.0.0) of rnoaa is on CRAN - NOAA Weather Data from R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.    A new version (v0.6.0) of brranching is on CRAN - Fetch Phylogenies from Many Sources. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.    A new version (v0.4.0) of originr is on CRAN - Fetch species origin data from the web. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.    A new version (v0.2.3.0) of opentripplanner is on CRAN - client for OpenTripPlanner for journey planning. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.    A new version (v0.9.97) of taxize is on CRAN - taxonomic toolbelt for R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the taxize book to get started.    A new version (v1.1.2) of dbparser is on CRAN - DrugBank database XML parser. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.    A new version (v1.0.0) of rbison is on CRAN - interface to the USGS BISON API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started. We‚Äôll highlight newly onboarded packages here. 2020 - if you want a brief summary of the last 2 months of these newsletters, these blog posts are for you (written by Stefanie Butland)Use CasesThe following 27 works use/cite rOpenSci software:  Wesener et al. used nlrx in their paper Stress priming affects fungal competition ‚Äì evidence from a combined experimental and modeling study 1  Deribe et al. used opencage in their paper Predicting the Environmental Suitability and Population at Risk of Podoconiosis in Africa 2  Parravicini et al. used rfishbase in their paper Global gut content data synthesis and phylogeny delineate reef fish trophic guilds 3  Vantas et al. used hydroscoper in their paper Estimating Current and Future Rainfall Erosivity in Greece Using Regional Climate Models and Spatial Quantile Regression Forests 4  Ashby used roadoi and rromeo in their paper Three quarters of new criminological knowledge is hidden from policy makers 5  Yu used treeio in their paper Using ggtree to Visualize Data on Tree‚ÄêLike Structures 6  Lequime et al. used treeio in their paper nosoi: a stochastic agent-based transmission chain simulation framework in R 7  Wei et al. used rotl in their paper Pollinator niche partitioning and asymmetric facilitation contribute to the maintenance of diversity 8  Fontanelli & Mansilla used rtweet in their paper Modeling the Popularity of Twitter Hashtags with Master Equations 9  Young et al. used taxize and rgbif and rbison in their paper A modeling workflow that balances automation and human intervention to inform invasive plant management decisions at multiple items.content_html:
Software üì¶

CRAN: GitHub:

New Versions

  • A new version (v2.4.5) of RNeXML is on CRAN - Semantically Rich I/O for the NeXML Format. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.1.0) of bold is on CRAN - interface to Bold Systems (http://www.boldsystems.org/) API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.1.3) of outsider.base is on CRAN - base package for outsider. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.1.1) of GSODR is on CRAN - Global Surface Summary of the Day (GSOD) Weather Data from R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.0.0) of rnoaa is on CRAN - NOAA Weather Data from R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.6.0) of brranching is on CRAN - Fetch Phylogenies from Many Sources. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.4.0) of originr is on CRAN - Fetch species origin data from the web. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.2.3.0) of opentripplanner is on CRAN - client for OpenTripPlanner for journey planning. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.9.97) of taxize is on CRAN - taxonomic toolbelt for R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the taxize book to get started.
  • A new version (v1.1.2) of dbparser is on CRAN - DrugBank database XML parser. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.0.0) of rbison is on CRAN - interface to the USGS BISON API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.



Software Review ‚úî


Software review is now accepting submissions again.

We accept community contributed packages via our software review system - an open software review system, sorta like scholarly paper review, but way better. We‚Äôll highlight newly onboarded packages here. A huge thanks to our reviewers, who do a lot of work reviewing (see the blog post on our review system),and the authors of the packages!

If you want to be a reviewer fill out this short form, and we‚Äôll ping you when there‚Äôs a submission that fits in your area of expertise.

The following package was recently submitted:

  • tidytags > Simple Collection and Powerful Analysis of Twitter Data
    • Author: Bret Willet
    • Issue: ropensci/software-review#382
    • Reviewers: not yet assigned



On the blog

It‚Äôs time for another installment of ‚Ä¶ 2 Months in 2 Minutes - rOpenSci News, June 2020 - if you want a brief summary of the last 2 months of these newsletters, these blog posts are for you (written by Stefanie Butland)



Use Cases

The following 27 works use/cite rOpenSci software:

  • Wesener et al. used nlrx in their paper Stress priming affects fungal competition ‚Äì evidence from a combined experimental and modeling study 1
  • Deribe et al. used opencage in their paper Predicting the Environmental Suitability and Population at Risk of Podoconiosis in Africa 2
  • Parravicini et al. used rfishbase in their paper Global gut content data synthesis and phylogeny delineate reef fish trophic guilds 3
  • Vantas et al. used hydroscoper in their paper Estimating Current and Future Rainfall Erosivity in Greece Using Regional Climate Models and Spatial Quantile Regression Forests 4
  • Ashby used roadoi and rromeo in their paper Three quarters of new criminological knowledge is hidden from policy makers 5
  • Yu used treeio in their paper Using ggtree to Visualize Data on Tree‚ÄêLike Structures 6
  • Lequime et al. used treeio in their paper nosoi: a stochastic agent-based transmission chain simulation framework in R 7
  • Wei et al. used rotl in their paper Pollinator niche partitioning and asymmetric facilitation contribute to the maintenance of diversity 8
  • Fontanelli & Mansilla used rtweet in their paper Modeling the Popularity of Twitter Hashtags with Master Equations 9
  • Young et al. used taxize and rgbif and rbison in their paper A modeling workflow that balances automation and human intervention to inform invasive plant management decisions at multiple spatial scales 10
  • Allen & Kim used rotl in their paper A permutation test and spatial cross-validation approach to assess models of interspecific competition between trees 11
  • Borgoni et al. used osmdata in their paper Assessing the Risk of Car Crashes in Road Networks 12
  • Dadi used skimr in their paper Modeling malaria cases associated with environmental risk factors in Ethiopia using geographically weighted regression 13
  • Pruchnik used hunspell in their paper Identification of Trends in the Polish Media on the Example of the Quarterly Studia Medioznawcze The Use of Big Data Tools 14
  • Pavlovich et al. used rentrez in their paper Egyptian Rousette IFN-œâ Subtypes Elicit Distinct Antiviral Effects and Transcriptional Responses in Conspecific Cells 15
  • Hagen et al. used rtweet in their paper Rise of the Machines? Examining the Influence of Social Bots on a Political Discussion Network 16
  • Chakraborty used MODISTools in their paper Multi-scale assessment of drought-induced forest dieback 17
  • Salgado & Oancea used RSelenium in their paper On new data sources for the production of official statistics 18
  • J√©z√©quel et al. used rfishbase in their paper A database of freshwater fish species of the Amazon Basin 19
  • Chapman et al. used rgbif in their paper Developing Standards for Improved Data Quality and for Selecting Fit for Use Biodiversity Data 20
  • Hamilton & Lahne used hunspell in their paper Fast and automated sensory analysis: Using natural language processing for descriptive lexicon development 21
  • Ranghetti et al. used geojsonio in their paper sen2r‚Äù: An R toolbox for automatically downloading and preprocessing Sentinel-2 satellite data 22
  • Moran et al. used rotl in their paper Poor condition promotes high-risk behaviours but context-dependency is key: A systematic review and meta-analysis 23
  • Lindner et al. used rotl in their paper Expression and Localization of Kcne2 in the Vertebrate Retina 24
  • Wang et al. used iheatmapr in their paper Characterization of the chromatin accessibility in an Alzheimer‚Äôs disease (AD) mouse model 25
  • Hoffman et al. used ijtiff in their paper Analysis of Dual Class I Histone Deacetylase and Lysine Demethylase Inhibitor Domatinostat (4SC-202) on Growth and Cellular and Genomic Landscape of Atypical Teratoid/Rhabdoid 26
  • Bastide et al. used treeio in their paper Efficient Bayesian Inference of General Gaussian Models on Large Phylogenetic Trees 27



From the Forum

We have a discussion forum (using Discourse) for the rOpenSci community. It‚Äôs a really nice way to have conversations on the internet. From time to time we‚Äôll highlight recent discussions of interest.


Many new use cases were shared in the forum over the past month since our last newsletter:

  • Iv√°n Mauricio Cely Toro shared: Create a time-lapse video using av package; it leveraged the av package, an rOpenSci package maintained by Jeroen Ooms
  • Andr√© Ourednik shared: Scrape an image from DeepZoom with R and magick, recomposing a single image from multiple tiles; it leveraged the magick package, an rOpenSci package maintained by Jeroen Ooms
  • Jay Timm shared: US lawmakers on Twitter during a pandemic: some corpus linguistics methods; it leveraged the rtweet package, an rOpenSci package maintained by Michael Kearney
  • Dave Parr shared: Testing an API wrapper with webmockr and vcr; it leveraged the webmockr and vcr rOpenSci packages



Call For Maintainers

Part of the mission of rOpenSci is making sustainable software that users can rely on. Some software maintainers need to give up maintenance due to a variety of circumstances. When that happens we try to find new maintainers. Check out our guidance for taking over maintenance of a package.

We‚Äôve had nine recent examples of maintainer transitions within rOpenSci:

  • RSelenium: now maintained by Ju Kim
  • chromer: now maintained by Paula Andrea
  • qualtRics: now maintained by Julia Silge
  • rsnps: now maintained by Julia Gustavsen and Sina R√ºeger
  • rdpla: now maintained by Alyssa Columbus
  • webchem: now maintained by Erik Sapper
  • mregions: in process of moving to maintenance by VLIZ
  • rWBclimate: now maintained by Sergio Ibarra-Espinosa and Amanda Rehbein
  • rinat: now maintained by St√©phane Guillou

We‚Äôve got one package in need of a new maintainer:

  • rflybase: The current maintainer is looking for a new maintainer. Email Scott if you‚Äôre interested.



Get involved with rOpenSci

We maintain a Contributing Guide that can help direct you to the right place, whether you want to make code contributions, non-code contributions, or other things like sharing use cases.





Keep up with rOpenSci

  • Mailing list: Sign up with an email address to get this newsletter sent to your inbox -> ropensci.org/#subscribe
  • Alternatively, you can subscribe to this newsletter via our XML feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.xml or our JSON feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.json
  • rOpenSci on Twitter: @ropensci
  • The rOpenSci blog at ropensci.org/blog - you can subscribe in any RSS aggregator, or manually via https://ropensci.org/feed.xml. We also announce new blog posts on our Twitter account.

From time to time we‚Äôll highlight recent discussions of interest.Many new use cases were shared in the forum over the past month since our last newsletter:  Isabella Vel√°squez shared: Package for downloading shapefiles using piggyback; it leveraged piggyback, an rOpenSci package maintained by Carl Boettiger  Adam Sparks shared: bomrang with a third party package, stationaRy, to get hourly weather data and clifro to plot wind roses; it leveraged bomrang and clifro, rOpenSci packages maintained by Adam Sparks and Blake Seers, respectively  Edwin Thoen shared: Using {drake} for machine learning; it leveraged drake, an rOpenSci package maintained by Will Landau  Sam Albers shared: Detecting the Effects of Sustained Glacier Wastage on Streamflow in Variably Glacierized Catchments; the use case is from a research article (Detecting the Effects of Sustained Glacier Wastage on Streamflow in Variably Glacierized Catchments) that uses tidyhydatCall For MaintainersPart of the mission of rOpenSci is making sustainable software that users can rely on. Some software maintainers need to give up maintenance due to a variety of circumstances. When that happens we try to find new maintainers. Checkout our Contributing Guide for why and how to contribute to rOpenSci.We‚Äôve had nine recent examples of maintainer transitions within rOpenSci:  RSelenium: now maintained by Ju Kim  chromer: now maintained by Paula Andrea  qualtRics: now maintained by Julia Silge  rsnps: now maintained by Julia Gustavsen and Sina R√ºeger  rdpla: now maintained by Alyssa Columbus  webchem: now maintained by Erik Sapper  mregions: in process of moving to maintenance by VLIZ  rWBclimate: now maintained by Sergio Ibarra-Espinosa and Amanda Rehbein  rinat: now maintained by St√©phane GuillouWe‚Äôve got one package in need of a new maintainer:  rflybase: The current maintainer is looking for a new maintainer. Email Scott if you‚Äôre interested.Get involved with rOpenSciWe maintain a Contributing Guide that can help direct you to the right place, whether you want to make code contributions, non-code contributions, or other things like sharing use cases.Keep up with rOpenSci  Mailing list: Sign up with an email address to get this newsletter sent to your inbox -> ropensci.org/#subscribe  Alternatively, you can subscribe to this newsletter via our XML feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.xml or our JSON feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.json  rOpenSci on Twitter: @ropensci  The rOpenSci blog at ropensci.org/blog - you can subscribe in any RSS aggregator, or manually via https://ropensci.org/feed.xml. items.content_html:
rOpenSci HQ

  • rOpenSci, together with many of our community members, put together a guide to help researchers find open data available in R: When Field or Lab Work is not an Option - Leveraging Open Data Resources for Remote Research. The blog post has information on a few topical areas, as well as a table of rOpenSci packages for access to research data.

Software üì¶

CRAN: GitHub:

New Versions

  • A new version (v1.1.2) of dbparser is on CRAN - DrugBank database XML parser. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.0.4) of fingertipsR is on CRAN - Fingertips data for public health http://fingertips.phe.org.uk/. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.3.9) of jstor is on CRAN - read data from JSTOR/DfR. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v7.12.2) of drake is on CRAN - a pipeline toolkit for reproducible computation at scale. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.3.8) of skynet is on CRAN - Bureau of Transport Statistics Data client. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.4) of europepmc is on CRAN - Interface to the Europe PubMed Central RESTful web service. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.7.4) of robotstxt is on CRAN - robots.txt parser and Webbot/Spider/Crawler permissions checker. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.3) of rgbif is on CRAN - interface to the Global Biodiversity Information Facility API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the occurrence manual to get started.
  • A new version (v1.0.0) of webchem is on CRAN - Chemical information from the web. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.2) of jsonld is on CRAN - JSON for linking data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the README to get started.
  • A new version (v0.9.1) of hddtools is on CRAN - Hydrological Data Discovery Tools. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.3.1) of pdftools is on CRAN - Text extraction, rendering and converting of PDF documents. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the README to get started.
  • A new version (v3.1.3) of qualtRics is on CRAN - download Qualtrics survey data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.9.96) of taxize is on CRAN - taxonomic toolbelt for R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the taxize book to get started.
  • A new version (v0.3.0) of geoops is on CRAN - GeoJSON topology calculations and operations. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.4.2) of xslt is on CRAN - extensible style-sheet language transformations. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the README to get started.
  • A new version (v1.0.0) of natserv is on CRAN - NatureServe R Interface. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.1.5) of textreuse is on CRAN - detect text reuse and document similarity. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.2.4) of tidync is on CRAN - a tidy approach to NetCDF data exploration and extraction. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.0-15) of CoordinateCleaner is on CRAN - automated cleaning of occurrence records from biological collections. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.



Software Review ‚úî


Software review is now accepting submissions again.

We accept community contributed packages via our software review system - an open software review system, sorta like scholarly paper review, but way better. We‚Äôll highlight newly onboarded packages here. A huge thanks to our reviewers, who do a lot of work reviewing (see the blog post on our review system),and the authors of the packages!

If you want to be a reviewer fill out this short form, and we‚Äôll ping you when there‚Äôs a submission that fits in your area of expertise.

The following two packages were recently submitted:

  • medrxivr > Access MedRxiv Preprint Data
    • Author: Luke McGuinness
    • Issue: ropensci/software-review#380
    • Reviewers: not yet assigned
  • coder > Deterministic Categorization of Items Based on External Code Data
    • Author: Erik B√ºlow
    • Issue: ropensci/software-review#381
    • Reviewers: not yet assigned



On the blog

Technical notes

Jeroen Ooms wrote about a new version of the rsvg package: Superior svg graphics rendering in R, and why it matters.



Use Cases

The following 26 works use/cite rOpenSci software:

  • Perez‚ÄêLamarque et al. used rotl in their paper Cheating in arbuscular mycorrhizal mutualism: a network and phylogenetic analysis of mycoheterotrophy 1
  • Larson et al. used brranching in their paper Ecological strategies begin at germination: Traits, plasticity and survival in the first 4 days of plant life 2
  • Rodrigues & Boscolo used taxize in their paper Do bipartite binary antagonistic and mutualistic networks have different responses to the taxonomic resolution of nodes? 3
  • Manel et al. used rfishbase in their paper Global determinants of freshwater and marine fish genetic diversity 4
  • Thompson used taxize and rentrez in their paper Experimental hybridization studies suggest that pleiotropic alleles commonly underlie adaptive divergence between natural populations 5
  • Gent et al. used taxize in their paper Population Diversity and Structure of Podosphaera macularis in the Pacific Northwestern United States and Other Populations 6
  • Bagheri used biomartr in their paper Domain-specific language and infrastructure for genomics 7
  • Heisel used rotl in their paper Ecological, Genomic, and Social Factors Impacting Wildlife Conservation 8
  • Hannah et al. used rgbif in their paper 30% land conservation and climate action reduces tropical extinction risk by more than 50% 9
  • Ryt-Hansen et al. used treeio in their paper Substantial Antigenic Drift in the Hemagglutinin Protein of Swine Influenza A Viruses 10
  • Armitage & Jones used CoordinateCleaner in their paper Barriers to coexistence limit the poleward range of a globally-distributed plant 11
  • M. et al. used rredlist in their paper Threatened Flora of Jammu and Kashmir State 12
  • Kaczvinsky & Hardy used taxize in their paper Do major host shifts spark diversification in butterflies? 13
  • Zizka et al. used taxize and rgbif and CoordinateCleaner in their paper Transitions between biomes are common and directional in Bombacoideae (Malvaceae) 14
  • Jung et al. used rgbif in their paper Comparative drought resistance of temperate grassland species: testing performance trade-offs and the relation to distribution 15
  • Howard & Cellinese used rgbif in their paper Tunicate bulb size variation in monocots explained by temperature and phenology 16
  • Du et al. used rgbif in their paper High correlation of species diversity patterns between specialist herbivorous insects and their specific hosts 17
  • Long & Turner used skimr in their paper Applied R in the Classroom 18
  • Reyes & Lira-Noriega used spocc in their paper Current and future global potential distribution of the fruit fly Drosophila suzukii (Diptera: Drosophilidae) 19
  • Lara-Lizardi et al. used osmdata in their paper Shark movements in the Revillagigedo Archipelago and connectivity with the Eastern Tropical Pacific 20
  • Cichosz used hunspell in their paper Unsupervised modeling anomaly detection in discussion forums posts using global vectors for text representation 21
  • Pietzke & Vazquez used writexl in their paper Metabolite AutoPlotter‚Äìan application to automatically process and visualise metabolite data in the web-browser 22
  • Kusumoto et al. used rgbif in their paper Global distribution of coral diversity: Biodiversity knowledge gradients related to spatial resolution 23
  • Potter used rfishbase in their paper Machine learning for resource economics; a review of modern computational statistics with empirical applications in fisheries management 24
  • Marshall et al. used rotl in their paper Developmental cost theory predicts thermal environment and vulnerability to global warming 25
  • Amiri Roudbar et al. used rsnps in their paper Integration of single nucleotide variants and whole-genome DNA methylation profiles for classification of rheumatoid arthritis cases from controls 26



From the Forum

We have a discussion forum (using Discourse) for the rOpenSci community. It‚Äôs a really nice way to have conversations on the internet. From time to time we‚Äôll highlight recent discussions of interest.


Many new use cases were shared in the forum over the past month since our last newsletter:

  • Isabella Vel√°squez shared: Package for downloading shapefiles using piggyback; it leveraged piggyback, an rOpenSci package maintained by Carl Boettiger
  • Adam Sparks shared: bomrang with a third party package, stationaRy, to get hourly weather data and clifro to plot wind roses; it leveraged bomrang and clifro, rOpenSci packages maintained by Adam Sparks and Blake Seers, respectively
  • Edwin Thoen shared: Using {drake} for machine learning; it leveraged drake, an rOpenSci package maintained by Will Landau
  • Sam Albers shared: Detecting the Effects of Sustained Glacier Wastage on Streamflow in Variably Glacierized Catchments; the use case is from a research article (Detecting the Effects of Sustained Glacier Wastage on Streamflow in Variably Glacierized Catchments) that uses tidyhydat



Call For Maintainers

Part of the mission of rOpenSci is making sustainable software that users can rely on. Some software maintainers need to give up maintenance due to a variety of circumstances. When that happens we try to find new maintainers. Checkout our Contributing Guide for why and how to contribute to rOpenSci.

We‚Äôve had nine recent examples of maintainer transitions within rOpenSci:

  • RSelenium: now maintained by Ju Kim
  • chromer: now maintained by Paula Andrea
  • qualtRics: now maintained by Julia Silge
  • rsnps: now maintained by Julia Gustavsen and Sina R√ºeger
  • rdpla: now maintained by Alyssa Columbus
  • webchem: now maintained by Erik Sapper
  • mregions: in process of moving to maintenance by VLIZ
  • rWBclimate: now maintained by Sergio Ibarra-Espinosa and Amanda Rehbein
  • rinat: now maintained by St√©phane Guillou

We‚Äôve got one package in need of a new maintainer:

  • rflybase: The current maintainer is looking for a new maintainer. Email Scott if you‚Äôre interested.



Get involved with rOpenSci

We maintain a Contributing Guide that can help direct you to the right place, whether you want to make code contributions, non-code contributions, or other things like sharing use cases.





Keep up with rOpenSci

  • Mailing list: Sign up with an email address to get this newsletter sent to your inbox -> ropensci.org/#subscribe
  • Alternatively, you can subscribe to this newsletter via our XML feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.xml or our JSON feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.json
  • rOpenSci on Twitter: @ropensci
  • The rOpenSci blog at ropensci.org/blog - you can subscribe in any RSS aggregator, or manually via https://ropensci.org/feed.xml. We also announce new blog posts on our Twitter account.

Software Review ‚úîIn the interest of reducing load on reviewers and editors as we manage the COVID-19 crisis, rOpenSci is temporarily pausing new submissions for software peer review. Please check back at our software review repository for updates. In this period new submissions will not be handled, nor new reviewers assigned. Reviews and responses to reviews will be handled on a ‚Äòbest effort‚Äô basis, but no follow-up reminders will be sent. Other rOpenSci community activities continue. We express our continued great appreciation for the work of our authors and reviewers.On the blogMa√´lle Salmon has two blog posts in the past two weeks:  Highlights of Hugo Code Highlighting - Software üì¶

CRAN: GitHub:

New Versions

  • A new version (v1.1.1) of dbparser is on CRAN - DrugBank database XML parser. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.4.0) of MODIStsp is on CRAN - Automate Download and Preprocessing of MODIS Land Products Data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.4.4) of RNeXML is on CRAN - Semantically Rich I/O for the NeXML Format. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.1.1) of colocr is on CRAN - conduct co-localization analysis of fluorescence microscopy images. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.3.2) of cRegulome is on CRAN - access, manage and visualize regulome (microRNA/transcription factors)-gene correlations in cancer. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.3.6) of eia is on CRAN - API wrapper for US Energy Information Administration open data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.3.6) of beautier is on CRAN - create BEAST2 input files programmatically. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.1) of tracerer is on CRAN - parse and analyze BEAST2 input files programmatically. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.3) of writexl is on CRAN - a portable, light-weight data frame to xlsx exporter. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the README to get started.
  • A new version (v0.27.1) of git2r is on CRAN - an interface to the libgit2 library, a pure C implementation of the Git core methods. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the README to get started.
  • A new version (v0.6.0) of stplanr is on CRAN - sustainable transport planning. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.0.0) of bold is on CRAN - interface to Bold Systems (http://www.boldsystems.org/) API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.3.4) of taxa is on CRAN - taxonomic classes for groupings of taxonomic names without data, and those with data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.9.95) of taxize is on CRAN - taxonomic toolbelt for R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the taxize book to get started.



Software Review ‚úî

In the interest of reducing load on reviewers and editors as we manage the COVID-19 crisis, rOpenSci is temporarily pausing new submissions for software peer review. Please check back at our software review repository for updates. In this period new submissions will not be handled, nor new reviewers assigned. Reviews and responses to reviews will be handled on a ‚Äòbest effort‚Äô basis, but no follow-up reminders will be sent. Other rOpenSci community activities continue. We express our continued great appreciation for the work of our authors and reviewers.



On the blog

Ma√´lle Salmon has two blog posts in the past two weeks:

  • Highlights of Hugo Code Highlighting - related to work on the rOpenSci website
  • A Roundup of R Tools for Handling BibTeX - including discussion of rOpenSci packages RefManageR, bib2df, and handlr



Use Cases

The following 23 works use/cite rOpenSci software:

  • Adil et al. used pdftools in their paper Identifying Trends in Data Science Articles using Text Mining 1
  • Finoshin et al. used rotl in their paper Iron metabolic pathways in the processes of sponge plasticity 2
  • Pimiento & Benton used paleobioDB and rfishbase in their paper The impact of the Pull of the Recent on extant elasmobranchs 3
  • Benhadi‚ÄêMar√≠n et al. used rgbif in their paper Distribution of Bactrocera oleae (Rossi, 1790) throughout the Iberian Peninsula based on a maximum entropy modeling approach 4
  • Ahrenfeldt et al. used treeio in their paper Metaphylogenetic analysis of global sewage reveals that bacterial strains associated with human disease show less degree of geographic clustering 5
  • Cinelli used hunspell in their paper Generalized rich-club ordering in networks 6
  • Alfaro-Ram√≠rez et al. used CoordinateCleaner in their paper Potential reduction of Hartweg ÃÅs Pine (Pinus hartwegii Lindl.) geographic distribution 7
  • Martinez-Feria & Basso used FedData in their paper Unstable crop yields reveal opportunities for site-specific adaptations to climate variability 8
  • Rego et al. used rnaturalearth in their paper Diversity of Bacterial Biosynthetic Genes in Maritime Antarctica 9
  • Cederwall et al. used taxize in their paper Life under an oil slick: response of a freshwater food web to simulated spills of diluted bitumen in field mesocosms 10
  • Mossion et al. used taxize in their paper A reference transcriptome for the early-branching fern Botrychium lunaria enables fine-grained resolution of population structure 11
  • Funk et al. used hunspell in their paper A Framework for Applying Natural Language Processing in Digital Health Interventions 12
  • Correia et al. used skimr in their paper RNA Sequencing (RNA-Seq) Reveals Extremely Low Levels of Reticulocyte-Derived Globin Gene Transcripts in Peripheral Blood From Horses (Equus caballus) and Cattle (Bos taurus 13
  • Verde Arregoitia et al. used taxize and pdftools in their paper Patterns in research and data sharing for the study of form and function in caviomorph rodents 14
  • Shivambu et al. used rgbif in their paper Impact assessment of seven alien invasive bird species already introduced to South Africa 15
  • Jhwueng & O‚ÄôMeara used rotl in their paper On the Matrix Condition of Phylogenetic Tree 16
  • Cooke et al. used rredlist in their paper Ecological distinctiveness of birds and mammals at the global scale 17
  • Palanisamy used pdftools in their paper An analysis on hidden markov model prediction factors using California wildfire and meteorological records 18
  • Panayiotou used rdflib in their paper An Ontological Analysis and Natural Language Processing of Figures of Speech 19
  • Ji et al. used rredlist in their paper Large-scale Quantification of Vertebrate Biodiversity in Ailaoshan Nature Reserve from Leech iDNA 20
  • Li & Guo used rgbif in their paper Substantially adaptive potential in polyploid cyprinid fishes: evidence from biogeographic, phylogenetic and genomic studies 21
  • Silva et al. used NLMR and landscapetools in their paper Revisiting reptile home ranges: moving beyond traditional estimators with dynamic Brownian Bridge Movement Models 22
  • Schwalb‚ÄêWillmann et al. used magick in their paper moveVis: Animating movement trajectories in synchronicity with static or temporally dynamic environmental data in R 23



From the Forum

We have a discussion forum (using Discourse) for the rOpenSci community. It‚Äôs a really nice way to have conversations on the internet. From time to time we‚Äôll highlight recent discussions of interest.


A few new use cases were shared in the forum recently:

  • Rami Krispin shared: Visualize covid19 cases using rnaturalearth package; it leveraged rnaturalearth, an rOpenSci package maintained by Andy South
  • Miles McBain shared: {drake} at Queensland Fire and Emergency Services; it leveraged drake, an rOpenSci package maintained by Will Landau
  • Alberto Cairo shared a use case for the rOpenSci package tradestatistics maintained by Mauricio Vargas



In The News

  • testing: Why You Should Document Your Tests
    • Should you document your tests? I for one, only sometimes include comments in my tests, but perhaps they should be documented better? Do you comment or document your tests? This blog post is about Python, but the ideas apply to any language.



Call For Maintainers

Part of the mission of rOpenSci is making sustainable software that users can rely on. Some software maintainers need to give up maintenance due to a variety of circumstances. When that happens we try to find new maintainers. Checkout our Contributing Guide for why and how to contribute to rOpenSci.

We‚Äôve had eight recent examples of maintainer transitions within rOpenSci:

  • RSelenium: now maintained by Ju Kim
  • chromer: now maintained by Paula Andrea
  • qualtRics: now maintained by Julia Silge
  • rsnps: now maintained by Julia Gustavsen and Sina R√ºeger
  • rdpla: now maintained by Alyssa Columbus
  • webchem: now maintained by Erik Sapper
  • mregions: in process of moving to maintenance by VLIZ
  • rWBclimate: now maintained by Sergio Ibarra-Espinosa and Amanda Rehbein

We‚Äôve got one package in need of a new maintainer:

  • rinat: The current maintainer is looking for a new maintainer. Email Scott if you‚Äôre interested.



Get involved with rOpenSci

We maintain a Contributing Guide that can help direct you to the right place, whether you want to make code contributions, non-code contributions, or other things like sharing use cases.





Keep up with rOpenSci

  • Mailing list: Sign up with an email address to get this newsletter sent to your inbox -> ropensci.org/#subscribe
  • Alternatively, you can subscribe to this newsletter via our XML feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.xml or our JSON feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.json
  • rOpenSci on Twitter: @ropensci
  • The rOpenSci blog at ropensci.org/blog - you can subscribe in any RSS aggregator, or manually via https://ropensci.org/feed.xml. We also announce new blog posts on our Twitter account.

items.content_html:
Software üì¶

CRAN: GitHub:

New Versions

  • A new version (v1.1.3) of lingtypology is on CRAN - linguistic typology and mapping. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.24.1) of rtika is on CRAN - R Interface to Apache Tika. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.3.0) of googleLanguageR is on CRAN - Google‚Äôs Natural Language, Cloud Translation, Cloud Speech, and Cloud Text-to-Speech APIs. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.1.0) of GSODR is on CRAN - Global Surface Summary of the Day (GSOD) Weather Data from R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.4.0) of natserv is on CRAN - NatureServe R Interface. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.9.0) of ritis is on CRAN - an R client for ITIS (Integrated Taxonomic Information Service). See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.3.4) of weathercan is on CRAN - Download weather data from the Environment and Climate Change Canada website. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.3.0) of citecorp is on CRAN - client for the Open Citations Corpus. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.0.3) of fingertipsR is on CRAN - Fingertips data for public health http://fingertips.phe.org.uk/. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignettes to get started.
  • A new version (v2.1.1) of skimr is on CRAN - compact and flexible summaries of data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignettes to get started.
  • A new version (v1.4.1) of xslt is on CRAN - extensible style-sheet language transformations. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the README to get started.
  • A new version (v0.2.1.0) of opentripplanner is on CRAN - client for OpenTripPlanner for journey planning. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.5.0) of fauxpas is on CRAN - HTTP error classes. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignette to get started.



Software Review ‚úî

In the interest of reducing load on reviewers and editors as we manage the COVID-19 crisis, rOpenSci is temporarily pausing new submissions for software peer review. Please check back at our software review repository after 17 April for updates. In this period new submissions will not be handled, nor new reviewers assigned. Reviews and responses to reviews will be handled on a ‚Äòbest effort‚Äô basis, but no follow-up reminders will be sent. Other rOpenSci community activities continue. We express our continued great appreciation for the work of our authors and reviewers.



On the blog

There‚Äôs a new version of the rOpenSci Dev Guide. The software review editors wrote a post describing the accumulated changes since v0.3: rOpenSci Dev Guide 0.4.0: Updates. Some highlights:

  • field and laboratory reproducibility tools is now an in scope category; see the Aims and Scope section
  • new section with security guidance
  • package documentation section changes

It‚Äôs time for another installment of ‚Ä¶ 2 Months in 2 Minutes - rOpenSci News, April 2020 - if you want a brief summary of the last 2 months of these newsletters, these blog posts are for you (written by Stefanie Butland)

Software Review

Matthew Lau wrote a post on their package (Rclean) that recently went through rOpenSci software review: Automatic Code Cleaning in R with Rclean

Technical notes

Matthew Strimas-Mackey wrote a blog post on Extracting eBird Data from a Polygon using the auk package.

Ma√´lle Salmon has a nice blog post about R Markdown and Hugo learnings! Miscellaneous Wisdom about R Markdown & Hugo Gained from Work on our Website



Use Cases

The following 20 works use/cite rOpenSci software:

  • Benito & Birks used MODISTools in their paper distantia: an open‚Äêsource toolset to quantify dissimilarity between multivariate ecological time‚Äêseries 1
  • Ceschin et al. used rgbif in their paper The Rhinella arenarum transcriptome: de novo assembly, annotation and gene prediction 2
  • Schmidt et al. used geojsonio in their paper Web-based Visualization of Daily Mobility Patterns in R 3
  • Oliphant et al. used rentrez in their paper Effects of Antibiotic Pretreatment of an Ulcerative Colitis-Derived Fecal Microbial Community on the Integration of Therapeutic Bacteria In Vitro 4
  • Louren√ßo used NLMR in their paper Eco-evolutionary implications underlying the emergence of a derived reproductive mode in fire salamanders 5
  • Lope & Dolgun used pdftools in their paper Measuring the inequality of accessible trams in Melbourne 6
  • Tetzlaff used rotl in their paper Thinking outside the box: Effects of environmental enrichment and rearing duration on head-starting success of box turtles 7
  • Wiscovitch-Russo et al. used HelminthR and rglobi in their paper Pre-Columbian zoonotic enteric parasites: An insight into Puerto Rican indigenous culture diets and life styles 8
  • N√ºst et al. used RSelenium in their paper The Rockerverse: Packages and Applications for Containerization with R 9
  • P√©rez-Goya et al. used MODIStsp and MODIStools in their paper RGISTools: Downloading, Customizing 10
  • Senior used fingertipsR in their paper Does Sure Start spending improve school readiness? An ecological longitudinal study 11
  • Mooney et al. used taxize in their paper A system wide approach to managing zoo collections for visitor attendance and in situ conservation 12
  • Gagn√© et al. used taxize in their paper Towards a global understanding of the drivers of marine and terrestrial biodiversity 13
  • Gomez Isaza et al. used rotl in their paper Living in polluted waters: A meta-analysis of the effects of nitrate and interactions with other environmental stressors on freshwater taxa 14
  • V√≠lchez-Rom√°n et al. used rplos in their paper Social dimension activates the usage and academic impact of Open Access publications in Andean countries: a structural modeling-based approach 15
  • Caseys et al. used iheatmapr in their paper Quantitative interactions drive Botrytis cinerea disease outcome across the plant kingdom 16
  • Van Zonneveld et al. used rgbif in their paper Mapping patterns of abiotic and biotic stress resilience uncovers conservation gaps and breeding potential of Vigna wild relatives 17
  • Kim et al. used biomartr in their paper netGO: R-Shiny package for network-integrated pathway enrichment analysis 18
  • Callanan et al. used treeio in their paper Expansion of known ssRNA phage genomes: From tens to over a thousand 19
  • Mattatia used CoordinateCleaner in their paper An empirical assessment of the extent to which the realized niche of bird species is truncated 20



From the Forum

We have a discussion forum (using Discourse) for the rOpenSci community. It‚Äôs a really nice way to have conversations on the internet. From time to time we‚Äôll highlight recent discussions of interest.


A few new use cases were shared in the forum recently:

  • Ma√´lle Salmon shared: Use of crul‚Äôs retry sub-routine in an API package; crul is an HTTP client package maintained by rOpenSci.
  • Peter Solymos shared a use case concerning magick, maintained by Jeroen Ooms - Animated generative art with {magick}



Call For Maintainers

Part of the mission of rOpenSci is making sustainable software that users can rely on. Some software maintainers need to give up maintenance due to a variety of circumstances. When that happens we try to find new maintainers. Checkout our Contributing Guide for why and how to contribute to rOpenSci.

We‚Äôve had eight recent examples of maintainer transitions within rOpenSci:

  • RSelenium: now maintained by Ju Kim
  • chromer: now maintained by Paula Andrea
  • qualtRics: now maintained by Julia Silge
  • rsnps: now maintained by Julia Gustavsen and Sina R√ºeger
  • rdpla: now maintained by Alyssa Columbus
  • webchem: now maintained by Erik Sapper
  • mregions: in process of moving to maintenance by VLIZ
  • rWBclimate: now maintained by Sergio Ibarra-Espinosa and Amanda Rehbein

We don‚Äôt have any packages looking for new maintainers - if you are a maintainer and want to hand over that role to someone else get in touch with us.



Get involved with rOpenSci

We maintain a Contributing Guide that can help direct you to the right place, whether you want to make code contributions, non-code contributions, or other things like sharing use cases.





Keep up with rOpenSci

  • Mailing list: Sign up with an email address to get this newsletter sent to your inbox -> ropensci.org/#subscribe
  • Alternatively, you can subscribe to this newsletter via our XML feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.xml or our JSON feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.json
  • rOpenSci on Twitter: @ropensci
  • The rOpenSci blog at ropensci.org/blog - you can subscribe in any RSS aggregator, or manually via https://ropensci.org/feed.xml. We also announce new blog posts on our Twitter account.
